dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.5.0.6491
dataIdInfo.idAbs: To date, there has been no global map of marine biogeographic realms based on statistical analysis of species distributions. We analysed the distribution of 65,000 species of animals and plants and distinguished 30 marine realms, a similar proportion per area as found for land. On average, 42% of species were unique to realms. The wider ranges of species in the pelagic and deep-sea than in coastal environments was reflected in there being 18 continental-shelf and 12 offshore deep-sea realms. The most widespread species were pelagic, both microscopic plankton and megafauna. Analysis of pelagic species recognised five realms within which other realms were nested. These maps integrate the biogeography of coastal and deep-sea, pelagic and benthic environments, and show how land-barriers, salinity, depth and environmental heterogeneity relate to the evolution of biota. The realms have applications for marine reserves, biodiversity assessments, and as an evolution relevant context for climate change studies.

Consts.useLimit:
Citation:

Costello, M., Tsai, P., Wong, S.P., Cheung, A.L.K., Basher, Z., 2016. Marine biogeographic realms and species endemicity. BioScience.XXX (In-Press)

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.5.0.6491

citeinfo.title: MarineRealms
citeinfo.othercit: Costello, M. J., Tsai, P., Wong, P. S., Cheung, A. K. L., Basher, Z., & Chaudhary, C. (2017). Marine biogeographic realms and species endemicity. Nature Communications, 8(1), 1057.

descript.abstract: Marine biogeographic realms have been inferred from small groups of species in particular environments (e.g., coastal, pelagic), without a global map of realms based on statistical analysis of species across all higher taxa. Here we analyze the distribution of 65,000 species of marine animals and plants, and distinguish 30 distinct marine realms, a similar proportion per area as found for land. On average, 42% of species are unique to the realms. We reveal 18 continental-shelf and 12 offshore deep-sea realms, reflecting the wider ranges of species in the pelagic and deep-sea compared to coastal areas. The most widespread species are pelagic microscopic plankton and megafauna. Analysis of pelagic species recognizes five realms within which other realms are nested. These maps integrate the biogeography of coastal and deep-sea, pelagic and benthic environments, and show how land-barriers, salinity, depth, and environmental heterogeneity relate to the evolution of biota. The realms have applications for marine reserves, biodiversity assessments, and as an evolution relevant context for climate change studies.
descript.purpose: This analysis have integrated data across all these environments to map species endemicity, and show how global patterns of species richness and endemicity compare between coastal and deep-sea, and pelagic and benthic, environments

idinfo.useconst: Free too use with proper citation.
idinfo.datacred: The primary data used here are freely available from OBIS (www.iobis.org). The aggregated species by 5Â° cell matrix finally used in the data analysis is available from. DOI 10.17608/k6.auckland.5086654.

timeperd.current: Costello, M. J., Tsai, P., Wong, P. S., Cheung, A. K. L., Basher, Z., & Chaudhary, C. (2017). Marine biogeographic realms and species endemicity. Nature Communications, 8(1), 1057.
